column1: ABP102Y1:Contemporary Canada::72L:This interdisciplinary
column2: foundational course provides an introduction to contemporary Canadian society. The course includes the study of geography
column4: literature and culture through a historical framework of the twentieth century. It also emphasizes particular themes including indigenous issues
column6: gender/women's issues and immigration/multiculturalism. Open only to Academic Bridging Program students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::JWU100Y1

column1: ABP103Y1:Introduction to the Study of Literature::72L:This discipline based
column2: writing intensive course introduces essential rhetorical and critical skills
column3: focusing on how to recognize major literary forms and how to read and analyze outstanding classic and contemporary literary works of drama
column4: poetry and fiction. Open only to Academic Bridging Program students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::ENG185Y1

column1: ABP104Y1:Environmental Issues Today::72L:This interdisciplinary course introduces the major issues regarding the sustainability of the global environment in the face of human development by integrating humanities and social science with the fundamental concept of environmental science. It examines major environmental problems
column2: such as rapid climate change and land degradation as well as the role and impact of government
column4: and ethics on environmental issues. Open only to Academic Bridging Program students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::WDW104Y1:Social Science:

column1: ABP105Y1:Indigenous Cultures and Societies::72L:This course provides an interdisciplinary focus on key topics relevant to Indigenous communities
column2: historically and in the present. Students will be introduced to diverse cultures
column4: and worldviews of Indigenous peoples of Turtle Island (particularly Canada) and how they have been affected by colonialism. Emphasis will be placed on the ways Indigenous peoples are resisting social
column10: and communities and creating space for the expression of Indigenous voices. Storytelling that prioritizes the perspectives and worldviews of Indigenous peoples will guide students’ learning about course topics
column12: and concepts. Students will be encouraged to connect their own storied identities and perspectives to course themes and issues. Classes will involve a mix of interactive lectures
column15: and field trips. Class time and assignments will also be devoted to helping students build their critical thinking
column17: and writing skills towards the completion of a research-based essay due at the end of the year. Open only to Academic Bridging Program students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::WDW105Y1:Humanities:

column1: ABP106Y1:Media
column3: and Society::72L:This interdisciplinary course provides an introduction to the cultural and social impacts of present-day popular mass media. Themes explored include the economic and political forces that shape the media world
column7: and social justice. The course examines a wide range of texts
column8: emphasizing popular culture produced in Canada
column9: and students will have the opportunity to draw extensively on their own interactions with popular media. Open only to Academic Bridging Program students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::WDW106Y1:Humanities:

column1: ABP107Y1:Introduction to University Studies in Mathematics::72L:This course focuses on mathematical concepts and skills needed for success in First Year university Math and Science courses. Students will develop quantitative reasoning abilities required to critique arguments and make decisions

column4: and workshop-style sessions enable students to strengthen the skills they learn. Open only to Academic Bridging Program students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::WDW107Y1:Science:

column1: ABP108Y1:Introduction to University Studies in Chemistry::72L:This course covers the fundamental knowledge and skills needed for success in First Year university Chemistry and other Sciences such as Biology. Topics include atoms
column3: and compounds; the chemical and physical properties of gases
column5: and solids; chemical reactions; and the importance of chemistry in understanding the world around us
column6: with attention to how it can address issues in medicine
column8: and sustainability. Open only to Academic Bridging Program students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::WDW108Y1:Science:

column1: ABP109Y1:Diverse Histories of Canada::72L:This course explores diverse
column3: such as Indigenous and racialized peoples
column4: within the territories currently known as Canada to challenge monolithic
column6: and uncritical representations of this country's past and future. Archival materials
column12: and other texts will be approached from interdisciplinary perspectives to reveal different orientations to historical events
column14: and futures of this territory. Open only to Academic Bridging Program students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::WDW101Y1:Humanities:

column1: ACT199H1:Decipher Financial Puzzles in the Media and Pop Culture::24L:Have you ever watched a pundit’s passionate rant over financial crisis on TV and wondered whether he was right or wrong? Did you get the full story after watching movies like Margin Call or The Big Short? What was the efficiency market versus behavioral finance debate all about? Did you wonder why everyone in the financial press seem to be calling for a lower debt/equity ratio on banks in the post-crisis era? If you find yourself think about those questions
column2: this is the course for you. We will start from some basic building blocks of finance
column3: such as time value of money and discounting
column4: and proceed to look at some of the important financial controversies you have read or heard in the pop culture or media. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::::

column1: ACT348H1:Life Contingencies II::36L:Determination of benefit premium and benefit reserves for life insurance and annuities; analysis of insurance loss random variables; theory of life contingencies for multiple lives. This is the second course in the life contingencies series
ACT349H1:Corporate Finance for Actuarial Science::24L/12T:Corporate finance for actuarial science students.:ACT240H1 (minimum 63%)

ACT350H1:Applied Probability for Actuarial Science:::The course offers an introduction to elementary probability theory and stochastic processes. The main goal of the course is to help actuarial students understand the concept of stochastic processes with particular emphasis on Markov chains that are of great importance in Life Contingencies and Property and Casualty insurance. The course will cover the following topics: a basic review of probabilities with emphasis on conditional probabilities and expectations
ACT370H1:Financial Principles for Actuarial Science II::36L:Mathematical theory of financial derivatives
column2: discrete and continuous option pricing models
column3: hedging strategies and exotic option valuation.:ACT240H1 (minimum 63%)

column1: ACT371H1:Basic Reserving Methods For P&C Insurance::24L/12T:Topics covered include reserving data and triangles
column2: diagnoses methods that range from triangle of ratios of paid claims to reported claims to triangle of reported claim ratios. The syllabus also includes projection techniques. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:ACT240H1

column1: ACT372H1:Basic Ratemaking Methods For P&C Insurance::24L/12T:This course covers the basic ratemaking methods for P&C insurance. It assumes that students are familiar with traditional reserving diagnoses and projection methods. The syllabus would introduce concepts related to earning of exposures
column4: large loss loading and credibility. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:ACT371H1::::Science:

column1: ACT390H1:Professional Experience in Actuarial Science::24S:This course is preparation for an internship work term. It includes various professional skill workshops

This is a CR/NCR course. This course does not carry credit weight and is evaluated as Credit/No Credit. No tuition fee is associated
column3: however a $625 ancillary fee will be assessed towards Professional Experience preparatory program costs.:Enrolment in the Actuarial Science Specialist program or by approval of the Department of Statistical Sciences.::::Science:

ACT471H1:Topics in Casualty Actuarial Science::36L:This course will cover current topics relevant to industry participants. Topics may include advanced modeling

column1: ACT475H1:Insurance Products and Regulation with AXIS::36L:Case studies using leading actuarial application AXIS. Examine key types of insurance products and their pricing and valuation. Review representative developments in insurance regulations in US

column2: emphasizing inquiry and critical analysis. Pre-colonial

column1: AFR250Y1:Africa in the 21st Century: Challenges and Opportunities::48L:A critical examination of Africa as a living space rather than merely a site of intellectual speculation and study. Uses scholarly and popular literature to explore the issues that engage the attention of ordinary Africans
column2: ranging from the dramatic to the seemingly trivial
column3: as they struggle to fashion meaningful lives in fast-changing societies. Topics include urban transition and city life; economic
column4: political and cultural impacts of globalization; new religious movements and changing conceptions of selfhood; new African diasporas in the West; dynamics of gender relations
column5: kinships and identities; and the politics of liberalization. Materials studied will include print and electronic news media and other mass media resources from Africa and across the world.::::NEW250Y1:Humanities

column1: AFR251H1:Language
column2: Freedom and Linguistic Human Rights in Africa::24L:Examines the language situation in Africa and the extent to which freedom and linguistic human rights are enabled
column5: achieved or protected by post-colonial African states. Using linguistic diversity in Africa as a backdrop
column7: discusses and assesses language policies that were adopted by post-colonial African states
column9: and the implications that these policies have for the rights
column10: freedom and empowerment of citizens of African states. Changes and evolving trends in language use and language planning are also discussed.:::AFR150Y1/  AFR250Y1/  AFR290H1::Humanities:

column1: AFR270H1:African Literature and the Politics of Storytelling::24L:Focuses on the art and politics of storytelling across the continent. Students will engage with various kinds of narrative genres from great African novels to short stories
column3: popular African films from Nollywood and other industries
column4: as well as more recent forms of storytelling from social media. Topics of discussion will include globalization
column10: artistic expression and African identities. This novel course offers a combination of a wide range of literary and non-literary narrative genres as well as a variety of theoretical and methodological approaches to textual analysis from decolonial theories to ecocriticism
column13: as well as more traditional methods of literary criticism and analysis.:::AFR150Y1::Humanities:

column1: AFR280Y1:Introductory Swahili::24L/72T:Introduction to grammar and basic vocabulary of Swahili. Emphasis on comprehension and oral practice. Reading of selected texts. Relation of the language to its East African cultural context.::::NEW280Y1:Humanities:
AFR290H1:The Idea of Africa::24L/12T:An historical examination of Africa as a conceptual category
column2: exploring discourses and representations - both African and non-African - that have produced our understandings of the meanings of Africa and Africanness.:::AFR150Y1::Humanities:

column1: AFR298H1:Popular Uprisings in Africa::24L:In recent years
column2: popular uprisings have mobilized thousands in over 40 African countries
column3: to demand a radical overhauling of existing economic and political systems. This course asks: What are the catalysts
column4: underlying causes and demands of these protest movements? What can we learn from the grassroots organizing that allowed these movements to gain momentum? How might scholars and activists analyzing the popular uprisings in their countries
column5: allow us to develop new vocabularies and frameworks for understanding popular protests and theories of revolution? Case Studies will include popular uprisings in Sudan
column12: Eswatini and Nigeria and reflect on similar movements around the world.:::AFR150Y1::Social Science:

column1: AFR322H1:The Contemporary African Novel::24S:Novels written in the last forty years by English
column2: French and Portuguese-speaking Africans. Ideological views concerning colonialism and neo-colonialism. Tradition
column3: religious and secular; the use of African symbolism. A small number of historical and sociological texts are recommended as essential background reading. Works not written in English are read in translation. (Offered in alternate years)::::NEW322H1

column4: as well as specific case studies on justice
column6: and gender relations. The influence of these richly diverse traditions is traced as well in the writings of African thinkers in the Diaspora.:::AFR150Y1:NEW351Y1

Also considers similarities and/or differences between youth languages and cultures in different regions of Africa and the general youth condition. Includes urban youth languages such as Sheng

column1: ANT200Y1:Introduction to Archaeology::48L/24T:How did art and technology develop in the course of human evolution?  What led to the development of agriculture and settled village life?  How did social inequality and urbanism emerge?  This course takes a global perspective to explore the archaeological evidence that sheds light on these questions and other aspects of prehistory and early history.  Students will engage with the challenges posed by new discoveries and also with recent developments in archaeological method and theory.  The goal of the course is to involve students with the current state of archaeological research and some of the major issues archaeologists work to address.:::ANT100Y1::Social Science:

column1: ANT407H1:Inka and Aztec States::24L:This course provides a comparative study of the emergence
column3: and transformation of the two historically-documented states of the native Americas: the Inka and the Aztec. Students will have the opportunity to analyze ethnohistorical and archaeological data in order to critically evaluate models of the pre-industrial state while gauging the anthropological significance of either convergence or particularity in the historical development of centralized political formations.:ANT200Y1/  ARH100Y1

column1: ANT430H1:Primate Conservation Biology::24L:The focus of this course is on the science of primate conservation biology in an anthropological context. Topics will include primate biodiversity and biogeography
column3: and conservation strategies/policies. The effects of cultural and political considerations on primate conservation will also be discussed.:ANT203Y1::::Science:

column1: ANT431H1:The Real Planet of the Apes::12L/12P:Through fossil labs and lectures
column2: we look back over 30 to 5 million years ago when apes roamed from Spain to China and Germany to Southern Africa. The fossil record of these apes
column4: reveals how we evolved our large brains
column6: extended growth period and incredible intelligence. We encounter many surprises along the way
column7: such as apes living with pandas in Hungary
column8: animals with a mix of monkey
column9: ape and pig traits and apes the size of polar bears. Of the more than 100 species of fossil apes known
column10: only one gave rise to us.:ANT203Y1::ANT335Y1 or  ANT330Y1::Science:

column1: ANT434H1:Health
column2: Diet & Disease in the Past::24L/12P:Advanced exploration of the life histories of past populations
column3: through the application of palaeodietary analyses
column4: palaeopathology and other appropriate research methods.:ANT334H1::::Science:

column1: ANT435H1:Anthropology of Childhood and Childcare::24L:A detailed review of the classic and recently emerging literature on the anthropology of children
column3: and childcare. Focus is on theories for evolution of human parenting adaptations
column4: challenges in research methodology and implications for contemporary research
column5: practice and policy in the area of care and nutrition of infants and children.:ANT203Y1 or  ANT208H1::::Social Science

column1: ANT436H1:Primate Ecology & Social Behavior::24L:This course will provide an overview of the ecology and social behavior of extant nonhuman primates. Topics will include socioecology
column7: and socio-sexual behavior. There will also be extensive discussions of methods used in collecting data on primates in the field.:ANT203Y1::::Science:

column1: ANT437H1:Introduction to Virtual Anthropology::18L/24P:Virtual anthropology is a set of new methods that allow us to digitize objects
column4: and bring them back into the real world. After a theoretical introduction
column6: photogrammetric software and 3D printers to digitize and study archaeological and anthropological specimens.:ANT334H1 or  ARH312Y1::::Science:

column3: this course presents a unique opportunity to explore intensively a particular Evolutionary Anthropology topic in-depth. Topics vary from year to year.:ANT203Y1 and a 0.5 credit 300+ level course from Group B: Evolutionary::::Science:

column1: ANT441H1:Love
column3: and Marriage::24S:Beginning with anthropology's early work on kinship
column4: and ending with recent analyses of sex work and the globalization of ideologies of romantic love and companionate marriage
column5: this course will investigate how emotional and sexual relationships are produced
column8: and experienced both within particular societies and transnationally.:ANT207H1 and  ANT343H1::::Social Science:

column1: ANT450H1:Multispecies Cities::24S:As of 2007
column2: for the first time in human history
column3: more than half the world’s peoples lived in cities. It is estimated that by 2030 over 60% will be urban-dwellers. This demographic shift suggests that for many (if not most) people
column4: their primary encounter with “nature” will be urban based. This course explores the idea of “urban-nature” by 1) focusing on the ways in which various theorists have challenged traditional ways of viewing both “the city” and “nature” and 2) encouraging students to develop their own critical perspectives through ethnographic engagements with the city of Toronto.:ANT204H1 or  ANT207H1 and a 300-level course or above in Society

column1: ANT455H1:Anthropology of the Middle East::24L:What can Anthropology
column2: as both an academic discipline and a way of knowing
column3: bring to our understanding of the Middle East
column4: a region deeply entangled in global geopolitics? What kinds of questions have social and cultural anthropologists asked when faced with the diversity of a region that stretches from North Africa to West Asia? This course explores the cultural
column6: and political complexity of the region from an ethnographic perspective
column7: while also attending critically to the way “The Middle East” has been constructed in the first place. Rather than attempting an overview of the entire region
column8: it focuses on themes that have compelled anthropological research in the area in recent decades
column9: including but not limited to war
column15: and religion. We will draw from key academic texts in conversation with other genres of knowledge production including film
column17: and literature. No previous familiarity with the region is required.:ANT207H1::NMC241H1
column20: ANT484H1 (Topics: Ethnography of the Middle East and North Africa) taken in Winter 2014
column21: ANT384H1 (Topics: Peoples of the Middle East and North Africa) taken in Winter 2017

column1: ANT456H1:Queer Ethnography::24L:This course explores
column3: how and where forms of desire and sexual practice have become sites of anthropological inquiry and exemplars of particular cultural logics. Tracing
column5: the transnational turn in the anthropology of sexuality
column6: the course engages important debates about culture
column8: and globalization. By focusing on the transnational movement of desires
column13: the course asks how sex is global and how globalization is thoroughly sexed. Course material will stress
column15: forms of same-sex or otherwise queer sexualities.:ANT207H1 and any 300-level course in Society

column1: ANT457H1:Anthropology of Material Culture::24L:The course addresses the cultural and social significance of material culture in specific cultural settings
column2: and the role that artifacts have played in the history of anthropological thought from early typological displays to the most recent developments of material culture studies.:ANT200Y1/  ARH100Y1/  ANT207H1::::Social Science:

column1: ANT458H1:Indigenous Health Histories and Canadian Settler Colonialism::24S:We focus on the relationship between the health and well-being of Indigenous people/s and Canadian settler colonialism
column2: drawing on scholarship from medical anthropology
column4: Indigenous studies and settler colonial studies. The course is centrally concerned with how Indigenous social and political actors have engaged with health
column6: social suffering and healing throughout the 20th century
column7: and informed by anthropological and historical understandings of healthcare systems as permeated by dynamic relations of power.:Any 300 or 400 level course in Society
column8: Culture and Language or  INS350H1 or  INS355H1 or  JFP450H1 or permission of the instructor::ANT345H1 or  ANT348H1 or  ANT358H1::Social Science:

column1: ANT459H1:Multispecies Ethnography::24S:This course introduces perspectives which extend anthropological inquiry beyond the solely human realm. Building on an acknowledgement of the fundamental interconnectedness of humans and other life forms
column2: it explores the agencies of other-than-humans
column8: ” and others. The course involves field-site visits and fieldwork projects in Toronto (GTA region) and engages with ethnographic methodologies best suited to investigations of inter-species
column9: inter-life form relationships.:ANT376H1 or three 300-level anthropology courses in any subfield or permission of instructor::::Social Science:

column1: ANT460H1:Global Perspectives on Women's Health::24S:This fourth-year seminar examines how female gender shapes health and illness. Using case studies of sexual health
column8: and socio-cultural factors that can put women at risk for a range of illness conditions.:ANT343H1/ ANT345H1/ ANT348H1::::Social Science:

column1: ANT462H1:Anthropology of Affect::24S:This course examines how anthropologists have studied the way that people hope
column4: and despise. Ethnography of the intimate realms of affect raises important questions about knowledge production and methodology as well as offering insight into how people come to act upon the world and what the human consequences of such action are. The course will also examine how the intimate is socially produced and harnessed in the service of politics and culture. Topics will include grief and its lack; dreams and activism; love and social change; memory and imperialism; sexuality and care; and violence and hope.:ANT207H1 and any 300-level course in Society

column1: ANT463H1:Anthropology of Racial Capitalism and Dispossession::24S:This course considers racial capitalism from an anthropological perspective through ethnographies and films which examine the role race
column2: colonialism and white supremacy play in shaping and enabling contemporary forms of capitalist accumulation by dispossession in everyday life. Considering dispossession broadly
column3: we will explore not only processes that dispossess people of property and land
column7: citizenship and life. We will also look at the ways people are organizing to reclaim what they have been dispossessed of or denied
column8: from anti-eviction movements and abolitionist organizing to struggles for reproductive rights
column9: food sovereignty and climate justice.:ANT204H1/  ANT207H1::ANT342H1/  ANT366H1::Social Science:

column1: ANT464H1:Black Ethnographies::24S:Black populations in the African Diaspora defy simple characterizations. In this course
column2: we will examine the experiences of Black people through an ethnographic exploration of their lives. The close analysis of ethnographic monographs and articles will illuminate the ways in which race
column10: shape the everyday for Black people in different cultural contexts. An additional focus will be a consideration of the experiences of Black anthropologists as ethnographers and scholars who are broadening anthropological discourses.:ANT342H1::::Social Science:

column1: ANT465H1:Ethnographic Practicum: Toronto Tours::24P:This course provides students with a partnered field experience by conducting ethnographic research on visitor tours in partner organizations in Toronto with faculty’s supervision. The project will be developed in collaboration with the partner organizations to offer students partnership-based experiential learning opportunities. Students will produce detailed ethnographic descriptions of tourist experiences
column2: analyze how media representations and tourism infrastructure shape diverse visitor experiences
column3: explore how existing infrastructure can be potentially repurposed for a decolonial or inclusive tour
column4: and develop skills to communicate their findings to the broader audience.:ANT380H1. Students who do not meet the prerequisite are encouraged to contact the Department.::ANT324H1::Social Science:

column1: ANT472H1:Japan in Global Context: Anthropological Perspectives::24L:This course examines how what we know as Japan and its culture has been constructed through global interactions. Topics include gender and sexuality
column5: and Japanese identity amid changing global power relations.:ANT204H1/ ANT207H1::::Social Science:

column1: ANT473H1:Ethnographic Practicum: The University::36S:Students carry out original ethnographic research projects on some aspect of life in the University of Toronto: its students
column2: staff and faculty; its hierarchies and habits; and the everyday practices in classrooms
column7: and residence corridors. Class time is used for collective brainstorming
column8: feedback and analysis.:ANT380H1 or permission of the instructor::::Social Science:

column1: ANT474H1:Ethnographies of HIV/AIDS: Risk
column3: and Care::24S:This course examines HIV/AIDS globally and ethnographically focusing on how gendered political economies create HIV vulnerability; the experiences of sexual minorities; how religious institutions shape practices of social care and exclusion; and anthropological critiques of HIV awareness campaigns and counseling as sites of governmentality.:ANT348H1 or  ANT345H1 or  ANT358H1 or  ANT343H1::::Social Science:

column1: ANT475H1:Reading Ethnography::24P:Students read several full-length ethnographies
column3: and debate what makes for sound ethnographic research and writing
column4: as well as what ethnography is and "should" be as a genre of writing and representation.:ANT207H1 and  ANT370H1::::Social Science:

column1: ANT477H1:Transnational Korea in and outside the Peninsula::24S:This course addresses reading ethnography as a tool to understand compressed and complex modernity such as Korean societies

column3: this course aims to develop students’ critical thinking on class

column1: APM421H1:Mathematical Foundations of Quantum Mechanics and Quantum Information Theory::36L:Key concepts and mathematical structure of Quantum Mechanics
column2: with applications to topics of current interest such as quantum information theory. The core part of the course covers the following topics: Schroedinger equation

column9: perturbation theory. More advanced topics may include: adiabatic theory and geometrical phases

column1: APM426H1:General Relativity::36L:Einstein's theory of gravity. Special relativity and the geometry of Lorentz manifolds. Gravity as a manifestation of spacetime curvature. Einstein's equations. Cosmological implications: big bang and inflationary universe. Schwarzschild stars: bending of light and perihelion precession of Mercury. Topics from black hole dynamics and gravitational waves. The Penrose singularity theorem. Joint undergraduate/graduate course -  APM426H1/MAT1700H:MAT363H1/ MAT367H1::::Science:

column4: multiple scales. (Emphasizes techniques; problems drawn from physics and engineering):APM346H1/ MAT351Y1

column1: APM446H1:Applied Nonlinear Equations::36L:Partial differential equations appearing in physics
column5: and engineering. Nonlinear evolution equations. Existence and long-time behaviour of solutions. Existence of static
column8: topological and localized solutions. Stability. Formation of singularities and pattern formation. Fixed point theorems
column10: bifurcation theory. Equations considered in this course may include: Allen-Cahn equation (material science)
column14: nonlinear Schroedinger equation (quantum and plasma physics
column21: and Chern-Simons equations (particle and condensed matter physics). Joint undergraduate/graduate course -  APM446H1/MAT1508H:APM346H1/ MAT351Y1::::Science:

ARH100Y1:Introduction to Archaeology::48L/24T:Archaeology entails an active process of uncovering evidence for and learning about aspects of the human past. The goal of this course is to involve students in current archaeological practice
column3: and the global structure of the human experience from human evolution through cities and empires. Students will critically engage with ideas both within and outside the discipline on working with descendant communities
column6: and the relevance of archaeology to contemporary issues from climate change to social inequality. This course can serve as an introduction for students planning to pursue an archaeology program or as an opportunity to engage with a fascinating topic that is relevant to disciplines ranging from science to humanities.::::ANT200Y1:Social Science:

column1: ARH205H1:Archaeological Inference::24L/6P/6S:This course explores ways that archaeologists investigate research questions and interpret archaeological evidence. It introduces some of the main conceptual tools that archaeologists use to make inferences
column4: and experimental archaeology. It also uses practical exercises to help students understand the basic logic of some of the methods that archaeologists use in their research
column5: such as dating methods and identification of spatial patterns. This prepares students for more advanced courses in archaeology.:ANT200Y1/  ARH100Y1::ANT100Y1:ARH305H1:Social Science:

ARH440H1:Photogrammetry and 3D Analysis of Material Culture::12L/12P/12S:With the increasing availability of powerful computers and software
column2: 3D modeling and recording has become commonplace in archaeology
column5: and other areas of cultural heritage research. In this course
column6: students will learn about a powerful new method for 3D recording known as photogrammetry. After a series of tutorials
column7: they will gain firsthand experience creating their own models of various subjects
column8: such as historical architecture and public art in Toronto
column9: and museum objects on campus. They will also learn how to analyze and present 3D content
column10: while thinking critically about the impact of how digital tools are currently being employed by and shaping the agendas of researchers in archaeology
column12: and related fields.:1.0 credit in ANT/ ARH/ FAH courses at the 300+ level::Previous experience with photography or imaging software will be helpful but is not required:ARH482H1 (Special Topics in Archaeology: 3D Modeling and Archaeological Analysis)

column1: AST101H1:The Sun and Its Neighbours::24L/12T:Our place in the Universe. Phenomena we see in the sky. What we know about the Sun

column1: AST198H1:Great Astronomical Issues::24S:There are some fundamental questions which humankind has asked itself over the centuries. Many of these involve astronomical origins
column3: and objects. Astronomers now have the tools with which to attempt to answer some of the most fundamental questions
column4: such as "Where did it all begin
column5: where are we in space and time
column7: and who and what are we?" This seminar will explore some of these great issues. The selection of topics will be made initially by the instructor
column8: but will be modified by the seminar participants at the first class meeting. Topics could include: stellar evolution and the future of the Sun
column10: origin and future of the Universe
column16: astronomy and the public. Participants will be expected to join actively in lively discussions and to prepare and lead some of the seminars. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::AST199H1:Science:

column1: AST199H1:Astronomy at the Frontier::24S:This seminar series aims at building up general scientific literacy
column2: by discussing selected topics in current astronomy
column4: and space science. We will delve into the physical foundation behind the questions being asked and how the answers are being sought. Students will have an opportunity early in the course to select topics of particular interest to them and this will govern the choice of readings as well. Topics could include: formation of stars; lives and deaths of stars; stellar corpses: white dwarfs
column6: and black holes; planets around other stars; recent results from Hubble and other telescopes; architecture of the solar system; exploration in the solar system; the invisible universe: dark energy and dark matter; first light; formation of galaxies; the age and future of the universe. Participants should be comfortable with basic mathematics and quantitative reasoning. Students will be expected to do independent research for essays
column8: etc. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.::::AST198H1:Science:

column1: AST201H1:Stars and Galaxies::24L/12T:What we know about the properties and life cycles of stars
column3: and of the Universe itself – and how we know it. How astronomers develop methods for understanding phenomena that span such vast ranges in distance and time. This course is intended for students with no science or engineering background.::::AST121H1

column1: AST210H1:Great Moments in Astronomy::24L:From the Copernican Revolution to twentieth century astrophysics. Emphasis is placed on the process of discovery which has led to major advances in knowledge about the Universe. The course includes an outline of some of the most significant puzzles of our day and an examination of the potential for new revolutions in our knowledge. This course is best suited to science students.::::AST101H1

column4: formation and evolution. Introduction to telescopes and instrumentation.:PHY132H1/ PHY152H1;  MAT136H1/ MAT137Y1/ MAT157Y1:::AST101H1/ AST201H1:Science:

column3: the solar system and life. Search techniques and possibilities for interstellar travel and space colonies are discussed.::::AST221H1/ AST222H1:Science:

AST301H1:Observational Astronomy::36P:A hands-on introduction to telescopes and observational astronomy for students with little experience in the physical sciences. Through laboratory exercises and observations of the sky
column2: students will learn the techniques that have enabled the major discoveries of modern astronomy
column3: from the expansion of the universe to the existence of Earth-like planets orbiting other stars. Hands-on activities will teach how telescopes work and how we can measure the distances
column5: and chemical composition of celestial objects. Basic arithmetic is used
column6: but no advanced mathematics. This course is intended for students without a formal science background to gain experience with hands-on observational astronomy.:AST101H1/ AST201H1/ AST251H1:::AST325H1

column1: AST310H1:Indigenous Worldviews & Astronomy::24L:An in-depth exploration of astronomy
column3: and the night sky through the lens of Indigenous knowledges
column4: primarily that of Indigenous peoples from Turtle Island. Indigenous peoples have lived on Turtle Island since time immemorial and have a sophisticated relationship with the night sky that is influenced by their worldviews and their relationships with the land. In this course
column5: students will learn about Indigenous perspectives for understanding nature and astronomy and learn to understand astronomy through these perspectives. Students will also learn about the intersection of western astronomy and ongoing colonization to understand the responsibilities of western astronomers for respecting treaties and Indigenous rights as well as presenting an Indigenous lens regarding space exploration.:Any AST 100-level or AST 200-level course:::::

column1: BCH340H1:Proteins: From Structure to Function::24L/6T:Proteins are the main functional units in the cell. In this course
column2: a detailed overview of protein structure and function will be given with strong emphasis on the basic principles in the field. Students will be introduced to folded and intrinsically disordered proteins. Biophysical methods to study protein stability and folding will be discussed
column3: as well as experimental approaches to determine protein structure and function. Students will be introduced to catalysis
column5: and the mechanisms that regulate enzyme activity. Finally
column6: proteomic methods to studying protein networks in cells will be presented. The course will offer a solid basis in protein biochemistry. It is recommended for those interested in pursuing graduate studies or professional degrees in health or medicine.:BCH210H1/ BCH242Y1::::Science:

column1: BCH370H1:Laboratory Course in Biochemical Techniques::48P:This course is designed to provide hands-on experience at an introductory level

This course is intended for students who are not proceeding further in biochemistry. It is highly recommended that students take this course in their third year as space is limited and priority will go to third-year students. This course will be offered in the FALL & WINTER terms. Attendance in the first week of class is mandatory in order to receive safety information and laboratory protocols. (Enrolment limited.) (Lab fees: $40):BCH210H1.:::BCH377H1

BCH422H1:Membrane Proteins: Structure
column2: and Function::24L:Structural features of membrane proteins
column3: their biogenesis and methods of analysis. Function of membrane proteins as transporters
column5: pumps and receptors. Molecular aspects of disease processes linked to membrane proteins.:BCH210H1/ BCH242Y1;  BCH311H1/  MGY311Y1/ PSL350H1::::Science:

column1: BCH425H1:Structural Biology: Principles and Practice::24L:Theory of modern biophysical techniques as applied to the study of the structure and function of macromolecules; emphasis on X-ray crystallography
column4: and other spectroscopic methods.:BCH210H1/ BCH242Y1. This is a problem-solving course and will require use of skills from introductory physics

column1: BCH426H1:Regulation of Signalling Pathways::24L:This course is focused on the molecular aspects of signal transduction
column2: covering how cells receive and then transmit signals via intracellular proteins such as kinases and phosphatase and how this ultimately regulates cell function. Specific topics covered include regulation and signalling by extracellular ligands including morphogens
column4: how signalling pathway crosstalk modulates cell function and low and high throughput methodological approaches used to elucidate signalling mechanisms.:BCH210H1/ BCH242Y1;  BCH311H1/ MGY311Y1/ PSL350H1::::Science:

column1: BCH428H1:Genomics of Microbial Communities in Human Health and Beyond::24L/12P:There is a growing appreciation that microbes do not operate in isolation but form parts of larger populations and communities (microbiomes) with unique considerations for human health. Combining lectures
column4: this course will cover how genomics can be applied to analyze microbial communities and the transformative discoveries that continue to result.:BCH210H1/ BCH242Y1;  BCH311H1/ MGY311Y1/ CSB349H1::::Science:

column1: BCH440H1:Protein Homeostasis::24L:Protein homeostasis is dependent on the coordinated synthesis
column3: localization and degradation of the thousands of proteins in a living cell. This course deals with selected aspects of the process with emphasis on: i) protein folding and the role of chaperones
column4: ii) protein degradation via the ubiquitin proteasome system
column5: iii) protein folding and quality control in the ER and iv) ER-associated degradation and the unfolded protein response. The course will serve as a foundation for those with an interest in how cellular protein levels and conformations are maintained.:BCH210H1/ BCH242Y1;  BCH311H1/ MGY311Y1/ PSL350H1::::Science:

column1: BCH444H1:Protein Trafficking in the Secretory & Endocytic Pathways::24L:This course examines the molecular details of the secretory and endocytic pathways in the cell. Some of the specific topics covered will include protein translocation into the ER
column2: chaperones and protein folding in the ER
column7: basic concepts in endocytosis and protein sorting in polarized cells. Emphasis is placed on current experimental approaches. A good understanding of basic biochemical methods is an asset.:BCH210H1/ BCH242Y1;  BCH311H1 (75% or higher)/ MGY311Y1 (75% or higher)/ PSL350H1 (75% or higher).::::Science:

column1: BCH445H1:Organelles in Cell Function and Death::24L:Advanced principles and concepts of cell biology are covered
column4: and dynamic behavior of cell organelles. The cellular processes regulated by organelles
column5: including the life and death of the cell and cellular communication
column6: are highlighted. The course will also cover techniques and technologies that have advanced studies of the cell.:( BCH210H1/ BCH242Y1)

column1: BCH446H1:Membrane Dynamics of the Cell Surface::24L:This course covers the principles and concepts related to molecular cell biology of the cell surface in multicellular organisms. Topics include: biophysical properties of cells
column4: dynamic remodelling of the cytoskeleton; cell-cell and cell-matrix interactions; maintenance of planar and apical-basal cell polarity; cytokinesis
column5: viral uptake by macropinocytosis and engulfment by phagocytosis. In addition to lectures
column6: groups of students will interpret a recent scientific paper related to the course material to be formally presented during regular class hours.:BCH210H1/ BCH242Y1;  BCH311H1/ MGY311Y1/ PSL350H1.:::CSB331H1

column1: BCH448H1:Structure and Function of the Nucleus::24L:This course examines the structure and function of the cell nucleus and the genome through the lens of biochemistry
column3: cell biology and evolution. A focus is placed on the major scientific developments that shaped our current understanding. Topics that will be covered are eukaryogenesis
column5: the structure of DNA and chromatin
column6: the transfer of information between genotype and phenotype
column7: the filtering of information found in the genome into biologically relevant molecules such as mRNA
column8: the processing and export of these products from the nucleus into the cytoplasm
column9: and the translation of mRNA into protein. We will also investigate how various organelles
column10: such as the endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria
column11: played a role in the evolution of the nucleus. Finally we will investigate how biological information is partitioned during mitosis.:BCH210H1/ BCH242Y1;  BCH311H1/ MGY311Y1/ PSL350H1::::Science:

column1: BCH449H1:Medical Biochemistry::24L/12T:This course will apply core biochemical principles to explain the pathogenesis of emerging diseases at the molecular level and describe advanced biochemical technologies used to understand and treat these illnesses. Students will be exposed to how biochemical principles influence medical diagnoses
column2: therapy and the development of new drugs.:BCH242Y1/( BCH210H1

column1: BCH450H1:Antibiotics and Antibiotic Targets::24L/12T:This course will cover the action of the biochemical targets of the existing antibiotics (nucleotide-
column5: the manner in which these pathways are inhibited in antimicrobial therapy and the biochemical basis of antibiotic resistance. The biochemistry and origin of naturally occurring and synthetic antibiotics will be introduced. (Enrolment limited.):BCH242Y1/( BCH210H1

column1: BCH473Y1:Advanced Research Project in Biochemistry::144P:This course provides opportunities to pursue an original individual research project in a particular area of biochemistry
column2: under the direct supervision of a Biochemistry Department faculty member. Students are responsible for arranging for supervision by a Biochemistry Department faculty member. To apply for enrolment
column3: students are required to complete the application form by contacting the Course Coordinator before the end of August. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:For Specialist:  BCH340H1;  BCH377H1; 75% or higher in  MGY311Y1. For Major:  BCH370H1; 80% or higher in  BCH311H1.:BCH478H1:::Science:

column1: BCH478H1:Advanced Biochemistry Laboratory::24L/84P:Experiments extend students’ technical abilities as well as their knowledge and application of practical theory. This course is designed as an advanced successor in a progression of biochemistry laboratory experiences in  BCH242Y1 and  BCH377H1 that will equip students with a spectrum of practical abilities that are of vital importance in scientific research. (Lab fees: $25):BCH340H1

BCH479H1:Advanced Seminar in Biochemistry::24S:This seminar course will foster close interactions between students and Faculty and encourage in depth discussion not only of results but the ways the results were presented and the rationales for experimental design. Critical thinking skills will be developed
column3: as students become presenters of results and take on the role of scientist presenting and analyzing new findings. Writing skills will be developed through an essay assignment. Students within the audience will also have access to the experimental papers and be encouraged to pose thoughtful questions about research and the ways that research can be communicated within the scientific community. Thus the new seminar course will foster an appreciation of scientific writing and give students a venue to develop their communication skills. The goal of the seminar course is to improve both the written and oral scientific communication skills of our Specialist students
column4: as well as to increase their knowledge of key papers in Biochemistry.:BCH340H1; BCH377H1; BCH378H1; and permission of Department::::Science:

column1: BIO120H1:Adaptation and Biodiversity::24L/15P:Principles and concepts of evolution and ecology related to origins of adaptation and biodiversity. Mechanisms and processes driving biological diversification illustrated from various perspectives using empirical and theoretical approaches. Topics include: genetic diversity
column11: and invasion biology. A lab coat is required. (Lab Materials Fee: $26):Grade 12 Biology or equivalent. Students without high school Biology must consult the BIO120 Office (bio120@utoronto.ca)::::Science:

column1: BIO130H1:Molecular and Cell Biology::36L/15P:One of the goals of modern biology is to understand how the basic building blocks of life give rise to biological form and function. This course provides students with a common lexicon to understand the key principles and concepts in molecular and cell biology
column2: with a focus on how the building blocks of life lead to functioning cells. (Lab Materials Fee: approximately $11). Lab coat and safety glasses are required for use in laboratories; students are responsible for purchasing these items (approximate cost is $26).:SBI4U and SCH4U (Grade 12 University Preparation Biology and Chemistry) or permission of department. Please contact bio130@utoronto.ca for more information.:::BIOA01H3

column1: BIO220H1:From Genomes to Ecosystems in a Changing World::24L/15P:Dynamics of genetic and ecological change in biological systems
column2: from genomes to ecosystems. Evolutionary genetic and ecological perspectives on wide-ranging topics including disease
column7: and global climate change. Applications of evolutionary
column9: and molecular-genetic principles and processes. Responsibilities of human societies in a changing world. (Lab Materials Fee: $26).:BIO120H1::BIO130H1

column1: BIO230H1:From Genes to Organisms::36L/15P:The genome is the "book of life
column2:
providing instructions to construct an organism. This course introduces genome biology and explores how the building blocks of life are networked into functioning organisms. We will investigate how cells perceive internal and external cues, how gene expression is shaped by this perception, and how these events give rise to tissues, organs, and whole organisms. (Lab Materials Fee: approximately $16). Lab coat and safety glasses are required for use in laboratories; students are responsible for purchasing these items (approximate cost is $26).:BIO130H1, ( CHM135H1,  CHM136H1)/( CHM138H1,  CHM139H1)/ CHM151Y1:::BIO255H1:Science:
BIO251H1:Form, Function and Development in Plants::24L/12T:This course is an introduction to structure, function and ecology of vegetative and reproductive processes in plants with a focus on flowering plants and gymnosperms. Topics of study in lecture and laboratory tutorials include photosynthesis, transport processes, plant reproduction, patterns of plant growth and development, and the role of hormones in plant development.:BIO120H1::::Science:
BIO255H1:From Genes to Organisms with Advanced Laboratory::36L/33P:The genome is the book of life
column3:
providing instructions to construct an organism. This course introduces genome biology and explores how the building blocks of life are networked into functioning organisms. We will investigate how cells perceive internal and external cues, how gene expression is shaped by this perception, and how these events give rise to tissues, organs, and whole organisms. The Enhanced Laboratory provides the opportunity for greater laboratory skill development in modern investigative techniques and is intended for students interested in conducting their own laboratory research. (Lab Materials Fee: $51). Lab coat and safety glasses are required for use in laboratories; students are responsible for purchasing these items (approximate cost is $26).:BIO130H1, ( CHM135H1,  CHM136H1)/( CHM138H1,  CHM139H1)/ CHM151Y1, cGPA 3.0::BCH210H1 (taken concurrently or previously):BIO230H1:Science:
BIO260H1:Concepts in Genetics::48L/12T:This is a problem based course which discusses classical, molecular, developmental, and population genetics and genomics with emphasis on model organisms for genetic analysis.:BIO230H1/ BIO255H1:::HMB265H1:Science:
BIO270H1:Animal Physiology I::24L/9P:Animal physiology is a biological sub-discipline that aims to understand, in physical and chemical terms, how animals work. This course uses examples from throughout the animal kingdom, in a comparative approach, to introduce and study homeostasis and the endocrine system. Accompanying laboratories reinforce concepts introduced in lectures and provide opportunities for students to experience firsthand the role that experimentation, data collection, interpretation of data, and communication of data plays in the nature of the scientific process. (Lab Materials Fee: approximately $11). Lab coat and safety glasses are required for use in laboratories; students are responsible for purchasing these items (approximate cost is $26).:BIO130H1::::Science:
BIO271H1:Animal Physiology II::24L/9P:Animal physiology is a biological sub-discipline that aims to understand, in physical and chemical terms, how animals work. This course uses examples from throughout the animal kingdom in a comparative approach to introduce and study the nervous and cardiorespiratory systems. Accompanying laboratories reinforce concepts introduced in lectures and provide opportunities for students to experience firsthand the role that experimentation, data collection, interpretation of data, and communication of data plays in the nature of the scientific process. (Lab Materials Fee: approximately $11). Lab coat and safety glasses are required for use in laboratories; students are responsible for purchasing these items (approximate cost is $26).:BIO270H1::::Science:
BMS100H1:Introduction to Book & Media Studies::24L/12T:Introduces the academic study of media in all its forms, including books and print media as well as modern electronic and digital media. Provides an overview of key theories of media, culture, and society and relates them to contemporary issues, enabling students to apply different critical approaches to their everyday experiences with media.::::SMC219Y1,  CCT218H5,  MDSA01H3:Humanities:
BMS200Y1:Book & Media Histories::48L/24T:Traces the long history of media in culture and society, including books and other communication technologies. Covers historical developments including orality and writing, printing and the book, image and sound reproduction, wired and wireless communication, electronic and broadcast media, and contemporary digital media. Examples and case studies will be drawn from a variety of different sociocultural contexts, media industries, and creative practices.:::BMS100H1:SMC219Y1:Humanities:
BMS201H1:Information Literacy, Writing, and Research for Book & Media Studies::24L:Develops foundational skills for students in Book & Media Studies, including academic writing, information literacy, media literacy, citation, qualitative and quantitative research, primary and secondary sources, library resources, and practical techniques for analyzing different forms of media.:::BMS100H1:ACMB01H3:Humanities:
BMS300H1:Special Topics in Book & Media Theories::24L:This course offers students the opportunity to explore key issues and questions in the theory of books and media. The exact topic will change depending on the instructor. Possible topics include but are not limited to: specific theorists, theoretical schools, or traditions; theories of particular aspects or forms of media; theoretical debates or comparative approaches; interdisciplinary theory.:( BMS100H1,  BMS200Y1,  BMS201H1) or  SMC219Y1::::Humanities:
BMS301H1:Special Topics in Book & Media Cultures::24L:This course offers students the opportunity to explore cultural questions and issues related to books and media. The exact topic will change depending on the instructor. Possible topics include but are not limited to: cultural studies approaches; issues of identity and representation; media and ideology; national, regional, or sub-cultural media; cross-cultural analysis; media genres, styles, and conventions.:( BMS100H1,  BMS200Y1,  BMS201H1) or  SMC219Y1::::Humanities:
BMS302H1:Special Topics in Book & Media Histories::24L:This course offers students the opportunity to explore book and media history and historical research. The exact topic will change depending on the instructor. Possible topics include but are not limited to: particular periods or areas in book and media history; histories of specific media forms or styles; histories of media representation; historical research methods and approaches; industrial histories; comparative histories.:( BMS100H1,  BMS200Y1,  BMS201H1) or  SMC219Y1::::Humanities:
BMS303H1:Special Topics in Book & Media Industries::24L:This course offers students the opportunity to explore the industrial contexts in which books and media are made. The exact topic will change depending on the instructor. Possible topics include but are not limited to: particular media industries; national or regional publishing or media industries; approaches to studying media and cultural industries; specific aspects of media production, distribution, or reception; the relationship between different media industries; convergence and consolidation in media industries.:( BMS100H1,  BMS200Y1,  BMS201H1) or  SMC219Y1::::Humanities:
BMS311H1:Open Topics in Book & Media Studies::24L:This course is reserved for unique topics not already covered in other courses. The exact topic will change depending on the instructor.:Completion of 9.0 credits::::Humanities:
BMS312Y0:Open Topics in Book & Media Studies::48L:Offered as part of the Summer Abroad Program, this course provides students the opportunity to explore book and media cultures and historical research. The exact topic will change depending on the instructor. Possible topics include but are not limited to: particular periods or areas in book and media history; histories of specific media forms or styles; histories of media representation and cultures; historical research methods and approaches; cross-cultural analysis; national, regional, or sub-cultural media; comparative histories and culture. Students should check the Summer Abroad Program website for details.:::BMS100H1/  BMS200Y1/  BMS201H1::Humanities:
BMS314H1:Media Revolutions::24L:This class offers a deeper examination of the intersections of technology and human thought, perception and culture. The advent of new media technologies, from literacy through to social media, will be examined as revolutions in technology, semantic fields of cultural meaning-making and human action. Students gain a strong focus on technological advancements as insights into cross-cultural change at significant turning points in book and media history.:( BMS100H1,  BMS200Y1,  BMS201H1) or  SMC219Y1:::SMC314H1:Humanities:
BMS316H1:Social Media & Digital Platforms::24L:Social media, digital platforms, and networked technologies are deeply embedded in our contemporary lives, both shaping and shaped by users. But what are their social, cultural, political, and economic impacts? What consequences do they have for how we think, feel, socialize, work, play, and understand ourselves? Students in this course will explore, examine, and debate these questions with reference to their everyday experiences and current examples.:( BMS100H1,  BMS200Y1,  BMS201H1) or  SMC219Y1:::SMC316H1,  CCT331H5,  MDSB15H3:Humanities:
BMS319H1:Media Ethics::24L:Provides students with a theoretical foundation that enables them to identify and analyze ethical issues in mainstream and non-mainstream media. Traditional principles of journalistic truth-seeking, objectivity, and minimizing harm are revisited in the light of global, interactive media, produced by both citizens and professionals.:( BMS100H1,  BMS200Y1,  BMS201H1) or  SMC219Y1:::SMC319H1,  MDSC63H3:Humanities:
BMS320H1:Media and Trauma::24L:This course explores the intersection of media studies and cultural trauma theory through decolonizing frameworks. Students will learn theoretical foundations of cultural trauma theory with which they will engage mixed media narratives including film, books, music, video games and social media. Throughout the semester, we will focus on the construction of survivor-centered narratives amidst norms of popular media cultures and industries.:BMS100H1,  BMS200Y1,  BMS201H1:::BMS301H1 (Special Topics in Book and Media Cultures: Trauma & Media), offered in Fall 2021, Summer 2022, Fall 2022;  BMS301H1 (Special Topics in Book and Media Cultures: Books, Media & Music), offered in Winter 2022;  SMC317H1 (Books, Media, and Music: Trauma), offered in Fall 2020 and Summer 2021:Humanities:
BMS331H1:The History of the Book: Elements of Bibliography and Print Culture::24L/12T:An exploration of the history of the book from ancient inscriptions to e-books. This course develops an awareness of the interplay between material object and conceptual categories in book history by focusing on significant episodes in the evolution of the book as a medium, such as the rise of the context and the introduction of print. This course also delves in the practices of bibliography, the features of typography, and the material details of the printing process, while also highlighting the interdisciplinary nature of book history from a global perspective. Typically, this course will involve in-person workshops and visits to print studios and rare books collections on campus.:( BMS100H1,  BMS200Y1,  BMS201H1) or  SMC219Y1:::SMC228H1:Humanities:
BMS332H1:The History of Reading: Readers, Readerships, Reception::24L:This course explores the history of reading. Attention is given to the pivotal episodes in this history with a focus on its changing modes and shifting cultural significance. By surveying the habits, institutions, and aims of reading, students in this course will gain a greater understanding of its rich history and its complex evolution, and will enable them to reflect on the critical place of reading in their daily lives.:( BMS100H1,  BMS200Y1,  BMS201H1) or  SMC219Y1:::SMC229H1:Humanities:
BMS350H1:Propaganda and Media::24S:This course assesses ways in which governments, political parties, news agencies and other groups and institutions use media to shape particular messages or describe current events. Each week the seminar will focus on a major historical event, the manner in which it was reported and interpreted, and principal challenges to that interpretation. A wide variety of media will be analyzed including: books, newspapers, film, radio, television, and the internet. Events such as the War on Terror, the Great War, the Dreyfus Affair, the Irish Famine, and the “Red Scare” are among some of the topics that will be discussed. Students will prepare unique assignments akin to the work done by communications officers.:( BMS100H1,  BMS200Y1,  BMS201H1) or  SMC219Y1:::SMC430H1 (Advanced Topics in Book and Media Studies I: Media Manipulation and History), offered in Winter 2016;  SMC470H1:Humanities:
BMS386H1:Book and Media Internship::48P:Credit is offered to a student doing an internship with a media organization. A faculty supervisor assesses and assigns the necessary written component cognate to the internship. Students are responsible for securing their own internship. A description of the internship, working bibliography, marking scheme, and academic supervisor’s support must be submitted for approval by the Program Coordinator and Director. More information and application forms are available at https://stmikes.utoronto.ca/bms-internship-form or from the SMC Principal's Office, smc.programs@utoronto.ca. Enrolment in this course is intended for Book and Media Studies Majors not enrolled in the Arts & Science Internship (ASIP) stream of the program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.:( BMS100H1,  BMS200Y1,  BMS201H1) or  SMC219Y1:::SMC386H1:Humanities:
BMS387H1:Advertising and Media::24L:This course presents a critical media studies approach to advertising and consumer culture, past and present. Advertising, marketing, branding, and promotion play a central role in capitalist societies and media industries, reflecting and refracting dominant cultural attitudes and ideologies. How does advertising shape what and how we consume? What are its social, cultural, economic, and environmental impacts? Students will learn to analyze the form, content, and ideology of advertisements, and think critically about the advertising they are subjected to in everyday life.:( BMS100H1,  BMS200Y1,  BMS201H1) or  SMC219Y1:::SMC387H1,  CCT316H5,  MDSB03H3:Humanities:
BMS389H1:Libraries, Special Collections, and Archives::24L:This course takes a hands-on approach to introduce students to different types of printed and manuscript primary and secondary sources. Students will learn to apply information literacy concepts, and library and archival theories to the analysis, critique, evaluation, and use of materials drawn from the University of Toronto’s collections of library, rare book, and archival materials. This course will touch on current topics within information literacy, including, but not limited to, digitization, the ethical collection and use of oral and written information; post-colonial practices; racial, cultural, and gender representations; and archival neutrality.:( BMS100H1,  BMS200Y1,  BMS201H1) or  SMC219Y1:::SMC300H1 (Special Topics in Book and Media Studies I: Libraries, Special Collections and Archives), offered in Winter 2017, Winter 2018, Fall 2018 and Fall 2019:Humanities:
BMS391H1:The Media Franchise::24L:Reflective of the broader logics of media convergence, media franchises spread their commercial interests and imaginary worlds across many multiple media. For media industries, franchises maximize profits by linking together movies, TV series, books, comics, games, toys, merchandise, and promotional paratexts to encourage consumption. At the same time, they are a platform for new forms of serial narrative, world-building, and transmedia storytelling, and generate vibrant, diverse fan cultures that are sometimes at odds with franchise producers. Drawing on a wide range of scholarly and critical work, this course examines popular media franchises from historical, economic/industrial, formal/aesthetic, and sociocultural perspectives.:BMS100H1,  BMS200Y1,  BMS201H1:::SMC301H1 (The Media Franchise"

column1: BMS392H1:Media Identities::24L:An exploration of media’s influence on the constructions and representation of identity and power relations across race
column2: gender and class in individual and collective spheres. Applies a social justice and intersectional framework to media technologies and industries in order to expose socio-political influence on identity and to position media consumption and production as potential vehicles for restorative mediations of marginalized identities.:( BMS100H1

column1: BMS393H1:Media Ecology::24L:This course presents an advanced introduction to Media Ecology
column2: an interdisciplinary field of inquiry which examines how media environments affect human affairs
column5: and values. Building on the assigned readings
column6: students will examine the various theories of Media Ecology
column10: and reflection. An interdisciplinary approach informed by literature
column15: and history will provide students with the opportunity to critically evaluate some crucial and controversial issues facing contemporary society.:BMS100H1

column1: BPM100H1:The Art & Science of Human Flourishing::12L/12P:A multi-cultural survey of recipes for a life of “flourishing
column6: as well as critical scholarship on concepts and practices of human flourishing. Students explore perspectives from the sciences and the humanities about what it means to flourish across diverse cultures and contexts
column7: each week covering a specific theme and set of practices that expand self-awareness

column1: BPM214H1:Socially Engaged Buddhism::24L:Explores how Socially Engaged Buddhism has developed in response to global conversations on systemic oppression
column5: and trauma. We examine the roots of Engaged Buddhism in countries such as Vietnam
column10: and its transformation into a global movement. Themes include Buddhist environmental activism
column12: along with research on the application of Buddhist teachings in healthcare

column1: BPM232H1:Buddhism and Psychology::36L:An overview of the encounter between Buddhism and psychology over the last century
column2: with cross-disciplinary study of topics such as self
column7: and insight. We explore how (and why) scientists
column9: and Buddhist reformers have reinterpreted Buddhism as “science” and how Buddhist contemplative practices such as mindfulness or compassion training have been transformed and promoted by modern psychology.::::NEW232H1

column1: BPM330H1:Mindfulness-Informed Interventions for Mental Health::36L:An exploration of how mindfulness-based approaches are being used in biomedical mental health interventions. We study mindfulness from historical
column7: with an emphasis on its Buddhist foundations and on concepts of the embodied mind. We look at how recent socio-political phenomena are inspiring diverse applications and adaptations of mindfulness-based interventions.:Completion of 9.0 credits::BPM232H1/  NEW232H1/  NEW232Y1:NEW330H1:Social Science:

column1: BPM332H1:Buddhism and Psychotherapy::36L:A multi-cultural and interdisciplinary study of therapeutically-oriented practices and theories of the mind. Areas considered include positive psychology
column6: with comparison to various Buddhist teachings and practices.:::BPM232H1/  NEW232Y1:NEW332H1:Humanities:

column1: BPM333H1:Buddhism and Cognitive Science::36L:An interdisciplinary exploration of how cognitive science may connect with Buddhist terms

BPM334H1:Science of Wisdom: Buddhist and Western Traditions::36L:Provides a conceptual and contemplative interdisciplinary exploration of “wisdom traditions.” Buddhist approaches to self-actualization and wisdom will be compared to traditions from Mesopotamia
column5: etc. Coursework includes guided experiential exercises for various traditions.:::BPM232H1/  NEW232Y1:NEW334H1:Humanities:

column1: BPM335H1:Meditation and the Body::36L:An overview of scientific research on the psychological and neurophysiological effects of meditation. We explore the effects of different meditation styles on brain structure
column3: neurochemistry and other biological processes. Effects of meditation on mental health
column8: and cardiovascular function are also a major focus. The use of meditation in the treatment and prevention of illness is critically reviewed.:Completion of 9.0 credits::BPM232H1/ NEW232Y1:NEW335H1:Science:

column2: Psychology and Mental Health::36L:Topics vary from year to year depending on the instructor.:::BPM232H1/ NEW232Y1::Humanities:

column2: Psychology and Mental Health::36L:Topics vary from year to year.:0.5 credits from the Buddhism
column3: Psychology and Mental Health Core Course Group.::BPM232H1/ NEW232Y1::Social Science:

column1: BPM338H1:Exploring Mindful Awareness::36L:An overview of mindfulness as a systematic investigation of subjective experience
column2: with a survey of classic descriptions and contemporary scientific literature. Students will explore meditative practices in class and maintain a meditation practice outside class.:BPM232H1/ NEW232Y1/ BPM332H1/ BPM333H1/ BPM334H1/ BPM335H1/ BPM339H1:::NEW338H1
column4: Psychology and Mental Health: Cultivating Consciousness)

column1: BPM339H1:Mind
column2: Consciousness and the Self::36L:An interdisciplinary study of theories of mind
column5: placing Buddhist traditions in dialogue with scientific theories of the mind in psychology.:::BPM232H1/ NEW232Y1:NEW339H1:Humanities:

column1: BPM381H1:Buddhist Perspectives on Current Social Issues::36L:Explores teachings and principles in Buddhist canonical sources and considers their application to a wide range of social
column3: and environmental crises we are facing today
column6: burnout and mental health. We explore how Buddhist teachings are applied and adapted across different sectors of society including healthcare
column7: education and business.:::BPM214H1/  BPM232H1/  NEW214H1/  NEW232H1/  NEW232Y1:NEW214Y1/  NEW336H1 (Special Topics in Buddhism

column1: BPM432H1:Advanced Research in Meditation
column2: Psychology and Neuroscience::36L:This seminar-based course prepares students for advanced research on meditation by exposing them to diverse theories
column3: tools and techniques used in the field. Students will learn about the scientific method and develop critical thinking skills; critique scientific research articles on meditation; practice communication skills; and propose their own original study on meditation.:::BPM232H1/  NEW232Y1/  RLG206H1::Humanities:

column1: BPM433H1:Advanced Exploration of Buddhist Psychology and Practice::36S:An in-depth
column2: interdisciplinary exploration of how Buddhist teachings are set in conversation with contemporary scientific research on topics such as suffering
column8: and hands-on experiential practice.:::BPM232H1/  NEW232Y1/  RLG206H1::Humanities:

column1: BPM438H1:Mindfulness Meditation: Science and Research::36S:An exponential increase of scientific research on aspects of Buddhist theories of mind and mindfulness meditation has contributed to the growing popularity of mindfulness across the sectors of healthcare
column2: education and business. Examines the theoretical and empirical basis of mindfulness-based interventions and applications in healthcare settings and beyond. Critically addresses the roots of mindfulness
column5: interventions and outcomes. Quantitative and qualitative research methodology will be reviewed
column9: and interpretive limitations of the scientific literature will be discussed. The course aims to build scientific literacy skills through the assessment
column11: and discussion of peer reviewed journal articles.:A statistics course (e.g.  PSY201H1
